awd_abstract_narration:
When prisoners return home to American cities, they may find that their neighborhoods have changed due to gentrification and demographic turnover. This study explores how gentrification and neighborhood change shape the reintegration trajectories of formerly incarcerated men, drawing from interviews with 75 formerly incarcerated men in a city that has gentrified extensively. This project will help us understand the extent to which gentrified and diverse neighborhoods help or hinder returning prisoners' reintegration.  Findings will allow us to inform decision-makers on best practices for reintegrating this large and growing population, which will make it less likely that they return to prison.

The interviews are evenly divided between three kinds of neighborhoods: 1) neighborhoods that have experienced demographic change alongside an increase in average income; 2) neighborhoods that have experienced demographic change without changes in average income; and 3) neighborhoods with little demographic or average income change since 1990.  Interviews with formerly incarcerated men from these three types of neighborhoods will allow for a comparison of reintegration trajectories across neighborhoods that have experienced different levels and kinds of turnover. These interviews are recorded, transcribed verbatim, and then coded to assess common themes across the interviews.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Social, Behavioral and Economic Sciences
org_div_long_name: Division of Social and Economic Sciences

por.por_cntn:
NSF funding allowed us to collect a broad array of data, including interviews with formerly incarcerated Black men, ethnographic data on neighborhood change, archival data on DC neighborhoods, and an observational study of physical change at the neighborhood level using Google Street View. In addition, NSF funding allowed for quantitative analysis of secondary data from the American Community Survey, the U.S. Census, the Justice Department, and the Metropolitan Police Department.

 

These data allowed us to publish an article in the journal, Crime and Delinquency, that demonstrates the importance of distinguishing between periods of neighborhood decline and ascent, between the effects of property and violent crime, and between racial change and socioeconomic change when analyzing the relationship between crime and neighborhood change. In addition, we submitted two articles to scholarly journals that explore the relationship between policing and gentrification in Washington, DC. We also began analyses for four additional papers. In all, we expect to publish seven articles based on the data collected and analyzed.

 

In addition to the articles, the PI drafted a book manuscript that explores how Washington, DC, came to be both the United States’ “Murder Capital” and its incarceration capital, and how and why the city has since gentrified. This book manuscript also makes it clear that there are two primary factors that shape how formerly incarcerated Black men experience gentrification: 1) the arrival of White residents into formerly all-Black neighborhoods; and 2) significant increases in the price of housing.

 

In addition to scholarly works, the PI published an OpEd in The Hill on the burdens faced by incarcerated DC residents due to their placement in federal facilities far from Washington, DC. And, our research team created a website, MappingGentrification.com that displays the findings in an interactive format.

 

The findings from this study will help policy makers make informed decisions in the realms of housing, public investment, cultural diversity, and tax policies. With the continued arrival of large numbers of formerly incarcerated people into Washington, DC as well as continued escalation in housing prices, these issues are of prime importance to policymakers.

 

This project provided the funding to hire and train community members, graduate students, and several undergraduate students – mostly from under-represented backgrounds – in sociological research methods. They learned to conduct interviews, write interview summaries, analyze qualitative data using Dedoose, analyze Census and ACS data, create ArcGIS maps, and write literature reviews.

 

 


Last Modified: 10/30/2021
Modified by: Tanya M Golash-Boza
